questions.text: In diagnostic radiography, Photoelectric effect can be best described as an:

options.label: A
options.text: Interaction between low energy incident photon and the inner shell electron

options.label: B
options.text: Interaction between high energy incident photon and the inner shell electron

options.label: C
options.text: Interaction between low energy incident photon and the outer shell electron

options.label: D
options.text: Interaction of the high energy incident photon and the outer shell electron

questions.correct_answer: A. Interaction between low energy incident photon and the inner shell electron
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Interaction between low energy incident photon and the inner shell electron

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The photoelectric effect in diagnostic radiography can be defined as the interaction between a low-energy incident photon and an inner shell electron , leading to the ejection of the electron and subsequent emission of characteristic radiation , crucial for creating image contrast.

questions.text: What is the composition of the focusing cup in an X-ray tube:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Nickel

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A . Tungsten is a material with a high melting point and is commonly used in X-ray tubes , specifically in the cathode and anode for its thermionic emission properties , but not typically for the focusing cup due to its thermal characteristics.
  • • Option A
  • • Tungsten
  • • material with a high melting point
  • • commonly used in X-ray tubes
  • • cathode and anode for its thermionic emission properties
  • • Option C . Lead is used in the protective housing of an X-ray tube to shield against unwanted X-ray emissions but is not suitable for the focusing cup due to its high level of X-ray absorption and lack of necessary electrical properties.
  • • Option C
  • • Lead
  • • protective housing of an X-ray tube to shield
  • • against unwanted X-ray emissions
  • • Option D . Aluminium is commonly used as a filter material in X-ray tubes to remove low-energy X-rays from the beam but is not used for the focusing cup due to its lower melting point and different conductive properties.
  • • Option D
  • • Aluminium
  • • filter material in X-ray tubes to remove low-energy X-rays
  • • from the beam

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The focusing cup of an X-ray tube is made of nickel, due to its poor thermionic emission and high melting point , which helps in effectively focusing the electron beam towards the anode.
  • ➤ focusing cup of an X-ray tube
  • ➤ nickel,
  • ➤ poor thermionic emission
  • ➤ high melting point
  • ➤ focusing the electron beam towards the anode.

questions.text: A person has an injury in the forefinger with glass and it is suspected that he has a retained piece of glass in his finger. What is the first investigation you will do?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Plain radiograph

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . CT scan , while detailed, is not the first choice for foreign bodies due to its higher cost and radiation exposure compared X-ray.
  • • Option A
  • • CT scan
  • • not the first choice for foreign bodies
  • • higher cost
  • • Option B . MRI is contraindicated as the first investigation for suspected glass in the finger due to the risk of the material being ferromagnetic and potentially causing harm.
  • • Option B
  • • MRI
  • • contraindicated as the first investigation
  • • Option C . Ultrasonography can be useful for detecting soft tissue foreign bodies but may not be as effective as other modalities for identifying glass.
  • • Option C
  • • Ultrasonography
  • • detecting soft tissue foreign bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The first investigation for a retained piece of glass in the finger is a plain radiograph , due to its effectiveness in identifying radiopaque objects and immediate availability.
  • ➤ first investigation for a retained piece of glass in the finger is a plain radiograph
  • ➤ Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 642
  • ➤ Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 642

questions.text: What are the mechanisms of heat dissipation in modern X-ray tubes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. All the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Radiation - In this process, energy is emitted from the X-ray tube in the form of electromagnetic waves , which help to dissipate heat.
  • • Option A
  • • Radiation
  • • energy is emitted from the X-ray tube in the form of electromagnetic waves
  • • Option B . Conduction - This refers to the transfer of heat through direct contact , such as from the X-ray tube to the surrounding oil , which conducts the heat away.
  • • Option B
  • • Conduction
  • • transfer of heat through direct contact
  • • X-ray tube to the surrounding oil
  • • Option C . Convection - Heat is transferred by the movement of fluid , such as the circulating oil around the X-ray tube , which carries heat away through convection currents.
  • • Option C
  • • Convection
  • • Heat is transferred by the movement of fluid
  • • circulating oil around the X-ray tube

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heat loss in modern X-ray tubes occurs through radiation, conduction, and convection , with circulating oil playing a key role in conduction and convection, and radiation being the predominant mechanism.
  • ➤ Heat loss in modern X-ray tubes
  • ➤ through radiation, conduction, and convection
  • ➤ circulating oil playing a key role in conduction and convection,

questions.text: The CXR of a 65-year-old male with a previous history of heart surgery is shown. Identify the device:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Prosthetic mitral valve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Prosthetic aortic valve. This would be the correct choice if the device were located above the line drawn from the left hilum to the right cardio phrenic angle , indicating the aortic valve's position.
  • • Option B. Prosthetic aortic valve.
  • • correct choice
  • • device were located above the line drawn from the left hilum to the right cardio phrenic angle
  • • Option C. Implantable defibrillator. These devices are usually visible on CXR due to their leads and the generator , which would not be confused with a valve prosthesis.
  • • Option C. Implantable defibrillator.
  • • devices are usually visible on CXR
  • • leads and the generator
  • • Option D. Pacemaker. Similar to the defibrillator , a pacemaker has leads and a generator that are distinctive on CXR and would not typically be mistaken for a valve prosthesis.
  • • Option D. Pacemaker.
  • • defibrillator
  • • pacemaker has leads and a generator

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The chest X-ray shows a prosthetic mitral valve , identified by its position below the line drawn from the left hilum to the right cardio phrenic angle , an essential radiographic interpretation skill for medical residents.

questions.text: A person at the airport with symptoms showing agitations showed following x- ray findings. He was carrying enema apparatus and laxatives. Which of the following is a wrong statement?

options.label: D
options.text: He is at risk of poisoning

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. He is malingering

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Abdominal CT imaging is required. This is typically done to further evaluate the contents within the gastrointestinal tract that might not be clearly visible on an X-ray, especially when suspecting internal concealment of substances.
  • • Option A. Abdominal CT imaging is required.
  • • done to further evaluate the contents within the gastrointestinal tract
  • • Option C. He is a body packer. This is likely correct given the X-ray findings and the presence of enema apparatus and laxatives , which are indicative of someone attempting to smuggle drugs internally.
  • • Option C. He is a body packer.
  • • X-ray findings and the presence of enema apparatus and laxatives
  • • Option D. He is at risk of poisoning. This is a correct statement as body packers are at risk of packet rupture , which can lead to severe poisoning or overdose.
  • • Option D. He is at risk of poisoning.
  • • body packers are at risk of packet rupture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The individual is not malingering but is exhibiting signs of being a body packer , a condition where drugs are internally concealed for smuggling , posing a significant risk of poisoning if the packets rupture .
  • ➤ individual is not malingering
  • ➤ exhibiting signs of being a body packer
  • ➤ drugs are internally concealed for smuggling
  • ➤ posing
  • ➤ poisoning if the packets rupture
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 274
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 274

questions.explanation:

  • • Option A. Air. Air displays the least attenuation for X-rays , resulting in more transmission of X-rays and appearing darker on radiographs.
  • • Option A. Air.

  • • Option B . Fat. Than air, appearing slightly denser on a radiograph.
  • • Option B
  • • Fat.
  • • appearing slightly denser on a radiograph.
  • • Option C. Water. Water has a moderate level of attenuation , appearing denser on a radiograph than air and fat but less than bone.

  • • moderate level of attenuation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Bone represents the highest attenuation of X-rays among the given options, due to its dense, mineral-rich composition , leading to a whiter appearance on radiograph.
